chapter.title: Deploying raw images
chapter.para: &productname; provides raw images that can be directly deployed to your device storage—a memory card, USB flash drive, or a hard disk. The options for which type of device you can deploy the image to depend on your particular hardware—follow your vendor documentation.

To initially configure the deployed image, you need to prepare the configuration data as described in and you need to copy the configuration data to a device (for example USB disk). The device needs to be connected to your host running &slema; during its first boot.
To prepare the setup, you need two separate devices. One for the raw disk image, where &slema; runs, and another one that serves as a configuration media.

sect1.title: Managing extensions
sect1.para: &slema; supports the kernel live patching extension. Bear in mind that the extension might require additional subscription.

note.title: SUSE Linux Enterprise Live Patching availability
note.para: The SUSE Linux Enterprise Live Patching extension is available only for the &x86; (except for the real-time kernel) and &zseries; architectures.

sect1.para: As the extension activation or deactivation is performed as a transactional-update and thus creates a new snapshot, you need to restart your system to boot to the new snapshot and apply the changes.

listitem.para: to keep the current kernel running while patching the system, otherwise you may get dependency conflicts during applying kernel updates
after applying the live patch, a cleanup of kernels is performed in the new snapshot. If not set, the snapshot keeps the previous kernel and performs kernel updates also on the previous kernel.

sect2.para: Additionally, set LIVEPATCH_KERNEL='always' in the /etc/sysconfig/livepatching file.

note.title: Matching version of the kernel-default-livepatch and kernel
note.para: To ensure that the live patches will be installed even after kernel upgrade, install the matching version of the kernel-default-livepatch package.
